paper_1.name: Pure Mathematics 1
paper_1.question_style: Answer all questions; may assess any Pure topic.

paper_2.name: Pure Mathematics 2
paper_2.question_style: Answer all questions; may assess any Pure topic.

structure.note: Pure Mathematics content is assumed knowledge and may be tested within Paper 3 questions.

qualification_aims_and_objectives: Understand mathematics and mathematical processes to build confidence, enjoyment, and a foundation for further study.
Understand coherence and progression, and connections across different areas of mathematics.
Apply mathematics in other fields, and understand relevance to work and society.
Use mathematical knowledge to make logical, reasoned decisions in problem solving and communicate rationale clearly.
Reason logically and recognise incorrect reasoning.
Solve challenging problems requiring choice of solution strategy.
Recognise when mathematics can be used to analyse and solve contextual problems.
Represent contexts mathematically; understand the relationship between context and model.
Use diagrams and sketches to explore and interpret solutions.
Make deductions, inferences, and conclusions using reasoning.
Interpret and communicate solutions in context.
Read and comprehend mathematical arguments, including justifications of methods/formulae, and communicate understanding.
Read and comprehend articles on applications of mathematics and communicate understanding.
Use technology (calculators/computers) effectively and recognise when use may be inappropriate.
Take increasing responsibility for own learning and evaluation of mathematical development.

overarching_themes.note: Applied across the whole specification; students are expected to develop these skills throughout teaching and assessment.

theme_1_mathematical_argument_language_a.general_requirement: Use notation from the Mathematical Formulae and Statistical Tables booklet and recall formulae/identities in Appendix 1.

skills.skill: Construct and present mathematical arguments using diagrams, graph sketches, logical deduction, and precise statements with correct symbols and connecting language.
Understand and use mathematical language and syntax as set out in the content.
Understand and use set theory language and symbols; apply to inequalities and probability.
Understand and use the definition of a function; domain and range.
Comprehend and critique mathematical arguments, proofs, and justifications (including applied contexts).
Recognise underlying structure and simplify/abstract appropriately to solve problems.
Construct extended arguments for unstructured problems, including those in context.
Interpret and communicate solutions in the original context.
Understand that many problems are not analytically solvable; numerical methods achieve required accuracy.
Evaluate accuracy/limitations of solutions, including those from numerical methods, using reasoned estimates.
Understand the problem-solving cycle: specify problem, collect information, process/represent information, interpret results, and iterate if needed.
Extract information from diagrams and construct diagrams to solve problems, including in mechanics.
Translate context to a mathematical model using simplifying assumptions.
Use a model with suitable inputs to explore situations (given model or student-selected/constructed model).
Interpret model outputs back in the original context.
Refine a model by considering outputs and assumptions; evaluate appropriateness.
Understand and use modelling assumptions explicitly.

statistics_large_data_set.purpose: Supports assessment of Statistics in Paper 3.
statistics_large_data_set.student_expectation: Students must become familiar with the large data set in advance; exams may assume familiarity and provide advantage to those who studied it.
how_it_can_appear_in_assessment: Use of data-set terminology/contexts without explaining them in ways that remove advantage
Use of summary statistics/selected data/statistical diagrams derived from the data set (in question or stimulus)
Samples related to data-set contexts where prior familiarity helps interpretation
Interpretation tasks that would be too demanding in an unfamiliar context
what_is_not_required: Students are not required to bring copies of the data set into the exam
Students are not required to memorise detailed values within the data set
statistics_large_data_set.maintenance: Data set reviewed annually; changes (if needed) notified to centres before the start of the two-year course.

subtopics.learning: Understand and use the structure of proof from assumptions through logical steps to a conclusion.
required_methods: proof by contradiction (including irrationality of √2, infinity of primes, and unfamiliar applications)
examples_in_guidance: Deduction via completing the square to prove positivity of an expression for all n
Exhaustion for primes 3 < p < 25 to show (p−1)(p+1) is a multiple of 12
Counterexample to show 'n^2 − n + 1 is prime for all n' is false

subtopics.learning: Use laws of indices for all rational exponents.
subtopics.equivalence_to_know: a^(m/n) is equivalent to the nth root of a^m (and related equivalences).

subtopics.learning: Use and manipulate surds, including rationalising denominators.
subtopics.detail: Includes simplifying algebraic surds using standard surd identities (e.g. involving √x and √y).

subtopics.learning: Work with quadratic functions and their graphs.
required_knowledge: discriminant and conditions for real/repeated roots
solving quadratics by factorisation, formula, calculator, or completing the square
solving quadratic equations in a function of the unknown (e.g. involving powers, trig, exponentials, logs)

subtopics.learning: Solve simultaneous equations in two variables by elimination/substitution, including one linear and one quadratic.
subtopics.detail: May involve powers of 2 in one or both unknowns.

subtopics.learning: Solve linear/quadratic inequalities in one variable and interpret graphically; represent inequalities in the plane.
requirements: handle brackets and fractions reducible to linear/quadratic inequalities
express solutions using correct 'and'/'or' language or set notation
graphical solutions using shading plus dotted/solid boundary conventions

subtopics.learning: Manipulate polynomials (expand, collect like terms, factorise, simple algebraic division) and use factor theorem; simplify rational expressions.
subtopics.constraints: Division required only by (ax+b) or (ax−b); denominators in rational expressions are linear or quadratic.

subtopics.learning: Use graphs of functions; sketch curves defined by simple equations including polynomials; modulus of a linear function; reciprocal graphs and asymptotes; solve graphically by intersections; understand proportional relationships and graphs.
includes: y = |ax + b| sketches and using these to solve equations/inequalities
y = a/x and y = a/x^2 with vertical/horizontal asymptotes parallel to axes
expressing proportionality using ∝ or y = kx-style constants

subtopics.learning: Composite functions, inverse functions, and their graphs.
subtopics.graph_fact: y = f^(-1)(x) is the reflection of y = f(x) in the line y = x.

subtopics.learning: Transformations of y = f(x): y = a f(x), y = f(x)+a, y = f(x+a), y = f(ax), and combinations.
subtopics.detail: Includes transformations of standard A Level functions; also graphs of |f(x)| and |f(−x)| from a given f.

subtopics.learning: Partial fractions decomposition.
subtopics.constraints: Denominators no more complicated than squared linear terms; no more than 3 terms; numerators constant or linear.

subtopics.learning: Use functions in modelling, including limitations and refinements.

pure_mathematics_topics_for_papers_1_and.topic_name: Coordinate geometry in the (x, y) plane

subtopics.learning: Equation of a straight line; lines through two points; parallel/perpendicular lines; use in context.
Coordinate geometry of the circle; properties and applications.
methods_and_properties: complete the square to find centre/radius
angle in a semicircle is a right angle
perpendicular from centre to chord bisects chord
radius to point of contact is perpendicular to tangent
applications: equation of a tangent at a specified point

subtopics.learning: Parametric equations; conversion between Cartesian and parametric forms; attention to parameter domain.
Use parametric equations in modelling.
examples: motion with constant velocity between points over time

subtopics.learning: Binomial expansion of (a + bx)^n for positive integer n; n! and nCr; link to binomial probabilities.
subtopics.extensions: Extend to any rational n for approximation; validity for |bx/a| < 1 (proof not required).
notes: recognise alternative notation forms for combinations

subtopics.learning: Sequences defined by nth term and by recurrence xn+1 = f(xn); identify increasing, decreasing, periodic sequences.
Sigma notation for sums; expected knowledge that sum_{n=1}^n 1 = n.
Arithmetic sequences/series: nth term and sum to n terms.
subtopics.proof_required: Proof of the sum formula, including sum of first n natural numbers.

subtopics.learning: Geometric sequences/series: nth term, sum to n terms, sum to infinity for convergent series; use |r| < 1; modulus notation.
Use sequences/series in modelling (e.g. savings schemes with arithmetic or geometric growth).
Definitions of sin, cos, tan for all arguments; unit circle approach; sine/cosine rules; triangle area formula; ambiguous case of sine rule; radians for arc length and sector area.
Small-angle approximations (θ in radians): sinθ ≈ θ, cosθ ≈ 1 − θ^2/2, tanθ ≈ θ.
Graphs/symmetry/periodicity of sin, cos, tan; exact values for specified standard angles and multiples.
sec, cosec, cot and inverse trig functions arcsin, arccos, arctan; graphs, domains and ranges; angles in degrees and radians.
Core identities: tanθ = sinθ/cosθ; sin^2θ + cos^2θ = 1; sec^2θ = 1 + tan^2θ; cosec^2θ = 1 + cot^2θ.
Double-angle formulae; compound angle formulae sin(A±B), cos(A±B), tan(A±B); geometrical proofs; applications to half-angles; express a cosθ + b sinθ as r cos(θ±α) or r sin(θ±α).
Solve trigonometric equations in a given interval, including quadratic forms in sin/cos/tan and multiple-angle equations.
Construct proofs involving trigonometric functions and identities.
Use trig to solve contextual problems (including vectors, kinematics, forces).
Know and use y = a^x (a > 0) and y = e^x and their graphs; compare shapes for a < 1 vs a > 1; include y = e^(ax+b)+c.
Know gradient of e^(kx) is k e^(kx); recognise exponential suitability when rate of change proportional to current value.
Define log_a x as inverse of a^x (a > 0, a ≠ 1, x > 0); know/use ln x and its graph; ln as inverse of e^x; solve equations of forms e^(ax+b)=p and ln(ax+b)=q.
Laws of logs (product, quotient, power) including negative and fractional k; includes log_a a = 1.
Solve equations a^x = b (change of base may be used).
Use logarithmic graphs to estimate parameters in y = a x^n and y = k b^x given x,y data.
linearisation: plot log y vs log x: intercept log a, gradient n
plot log y vs x: intercept log k, gradient log b

subtopics.learning: Exponential growth/decay modelling (e.g. continuous compounding, radioactive decay, drug concentration decay, population growth); consider limitations and possible refinements; find model constants; interpret 'initial' as t=0; explore large t behaviour.

Derivative as gradient of tangent and as a limit; interpretation as rate of change; use f'(x) and f''(x); sketch gradient functions; second derivative linked to convex/concave and inflection points; differentiate from first principles for small integer powers and for sin and cos.
Differentiate x^n for rational n; sums/differences/constant multiples; differentiate e^(kx), a^(kx), sin(kx), cos(kx), tan(kx); derivative of ln x; know d/dx (a^(kx)) = k a^(kx) ln a.

Apply differentiation to find gradients, tangents, normals; stationary points (max/min); points of inflection; increasing/decreasing intervals; applications to curve sketching and contextual optimisation.

Product, quotient, chain rules; connected rates of change; inverse functions; include derivatives of cosec, cot, sec; use dy/dx = 1/(dx/dy) when differentiating x as a function of y; expect composite/product/quotient forms.
Implicit and parametric differentiation (first derivative only); tangents/normals to parametric/implicit curves.
Construct simple first-order differential equations in pure and contextual settings (e.g. kinematics, population growth, price-demand); set up DE from given proportionality statements.
Fundamental Theorem of Calculus; integration as reverse of differentiation; constant of integration for indefinite integrals.
Integrate x^n (n ≠ −1) and standard functions e^(kx), 1/x, sin(kx), cos(kx); use trig identities where needed; find curve given f'(x) and a point.
Definite integrals; area under a curve and between curves (including parametric curves); bounded regions with lines/curves.
Integration as limit of a sum; recognise definite integral as limit of summation.

Integration by substitution and by parts (simple cases); interpret as inverses of chain/product rules; substitution limited to single-substitution integrable cases; by parts may require more than one application; excludes reduction formulae; recognise ∫ f'(x)/f(x) dx = ln|f(x)| + c; include ∫ ln x dx.
Integrate partial fractions linear in the denominator; includes related rational expressions from earlier content.
Solve simple first-order separable differential equations analytically, including particular solutions; may require factorisation to separate; sketch family of solutions may be required.
Interpret DE solutions in context; identify limitations (including large-value validity); links to kinematics.
Locate roots of f(x)=0 via change of sign on a suitable interval; understand failure modes (interval too large; discontinuity/asymptote).
Iterative methods xn+1 = f(xn) to solve x = f(x); draw cobweb and staircase diagrams; interpret convergence geometrically.
Newton–Raphson and other recurrences xn+1 = g(xn); understand failure near small gradients.
Numerical integration: trapezium rule; estimate area and bounds; determine over-/under-estimate using curvature/sketch.
Use numerical methods to solve contextual problems; iterations may be suggested for equations not solvable analytically.
Use vectors in 2D and 3D; familiar with column vectors and i, j (and k in 3D).
Magnitude and direction; convert between component and magnitude/direction; unit vectors; notation |a|.
Vector addition and scalar multiplication; diagrammatic addition (triangle/parallelogram laws); parallel vectors.
Position vectors; distance between two points (2D and 3D) represented by position vectors.

Solve problems using vectors in pure and context (including forces); e.g. find unknown vertex position vectors in shapes like parallelograms; links to mechanics contexts (velocity, displacement, forces).

synoptic_assessment.definition: Requires working across different parts of the qualification to show accumulated knowledge and understanding with breadth and depth.

assessment_information_and_synopticity.sample_assessment_materials: Available via Pearson Edexcel SAMs (sample paper and mark scheme).

paper_3_statistics_and_mechanics_topics.note: Pure Mathematics assumed knowledge for Paper 3 and may be tested within questions.

subtopics.learning: Use terms 'population' and 'sample'; use samples to make informal inferences; discuss census vs sample pros/cons; understand and use sampling techniques; critique technique choice; understand different samples can yield different conclusions.
Interpret single-variable diagrams; understand histogram area represents frequency; connect to probability distributions.

Interpret scatter diagrams and regression lines for bivariate data; recognise distinct sub-populations; regression-line calculations excluded; understand explanatory vs response variables; use interpolation and warn against extrapolation; variables may not be labelled x and y; change of variable may be required to linearise relations.
subtopics.explicit_point: Correlation does not imply causation; use terms positive/negative/zero and strong/weak.

subtopics.learning: Interpret measures of central tendency and variation, extending to standard deviation; handle discrete/continuous/grouped/ungrouped; coding; calculate standard deviation including from summary statistics; linear interpolation for percentiles from grouped data.

Recognise and interpret possible outliers; rules (e.g. Q1−1.5IQR, Q3+1.5IQR, mean±3sd) will be specified when needed; select/critique presentation techniques; clean data (missing data, errors, outliers).
